asked.text: If we agree all industrial policy is sub-optimal for growth, why are tariffs worse than subsidies? They feel like the carbon tax of industrial policy — targeting the externality rather than picking winners.
Why does Texas have more permitted solar and wind than California despite the political narratives saying it shouldn’t?
Are progress studies actually a branch of moral philosophy or just the place where economics and ethics pretend not to notice each other?

learned.text: Vannevar Bush wasn’t just influential — he might be the last person who made the U.S. research system make sense.
Hayek and Foucault both end up defending individual agency, even though they arrive there from completely different worlds.
Robert Moses is a kind of folk hero for YIMBYs.

mused.text: From Noise: “the model of me is more consistent than me.” If that’s true, capitalism may work mostly because our unpredictability overwhelms attempts at planning.
Weightlifting while listenting to a long podcast is kind of fun.
Pluribus might be a puzzle box built out of questions about the good life rather than plot.
